Bhimrao Ramji Ambedkar (14 April 1891 - 6
December 1956), popularly known as Babasaheb, was an Indian lawyer, politician and academic who inspired the Dalit Buddhist movement and campaigned against social discrimination in India, striving for equal rights for the Dalit. As independent India's first law minister, he was the principal architect of the Constitution of India. Overcoming numerous social and financial obstacles, Ambedkar became one of the first "untouchables" to obtain a college education in India. Eventually earning law degrees and multiple doctorates for his study and research in law, economics and political science from Columbia University and the London School of Economics, Ambedkar returned home a famous scholar and practiced law for a few years before publishing journals advocating political rights and social freedom for India's untouchables. In his early career he was a private tutor, professor, and lawyer. His later life was marked by his political activities, where he became involved in the negotiations for India's independence, contributing significantly to the establishment of the state of India. In 1956 he converted to Buddhism, initiating mass conversions of Dalits. He has been given the degree of Bodhisattva by Indian Buddhist Bhikkues. Ambedkar was
posthumously awarded the Bharat Ratna, India's highest civilian award, in 1990.

column397: The French War Memorial in Pondicherry is a beautiful and poignant tribute to the soldiers who lost their lives during World War I. Located on Goubert Avenue, also known as Beach Road, the memorial is a simple yet striking structure. It consists of four white pillars that support a flat roof, under which lies a sculpture of a soldier with a gun on his side, standing guard over the memory of his fallen comrades. The sculpture is flanked by two walls, one of which bears the inscription "Aux Combattants Des Indes Francaises Morts Pour La Patrie 1914-1918", which translates to "To the fighters of French India who died for the motherland 1914-1918" in English. The other wall has the names of the soldiers who sacrificed their lives during the war. The surroundings of the memorial are well-maintained, with green lawns and trees providing a peaceful and serene environment for visitors to pay their respects. The French War Memorial is a beautiful and moving reminder of the sacrifices made by the soldiers and a tribute to the enduring relationship between France and India.

The statue of Marcus Dupleix is one of the most iconic landmarks of Pondicherry, a beautiful coastal city in South India. The statue is located at the end of Goubert Avenue, also known as Beach Road, facing the Bay of Bengal.

Marcus Dupleix was a French governor who played a significant role in the development of Pondicherry during the colonial era. He served as the governor of Pondicherry from 1742 to 1754 and is credited with establishing the French East India Company in India.

The statue of Dupleix is a magnificent bronze sculpture that stands tall at around 3.5 meters high. The statue depicts the governor in a commanding pose, with one hand resting on his hip and the other hand holding a sword. He is dressed in traditional French attire, complete with a long coat and a tricorn hat.

In addition to the stunning sights, the local cuisine was a true delight. From the delicious seafood to the mouth-watering French pastries, every meal was a treat for the taste buds.

Finally, the people of Pondicherry were incredibly friendly and welcoming, making my stay even more enjoyable. Their warmth and hospitality truly made me feel at home.

Overall, my Pondicherry trip was an unforgettable experience, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a unique and memorable travel destination.
